Fu

sen.j: 中国
sen.e: China
China
China
"Zang (Warehouse)"
sen.cmt: 中国語の「蔵」の読み方は、下記のサイトを参照にしました。｛http://www.chinese-tools.com/tools/sinograms.html?q=%E8%94%B5｝
sen.e: "Zang (Warehouse)"
"Zang (Warehouse)"

sen.j: 1. 原意は、古代中国で官物や財貨を収蔵した倉庫。
sen.e: 1. The original meaning is "the warehouse where government properties or goods were stored" in ancient China.
1. The original meaning is "the warehouse where government properties or goods were stored" in ancient China.
1. The original meaning is the warehouse where government properties or goods were stored in ancient China.

sen.j: 2. 農業が盛んで収穫が高く豊かな土地。
sen.e: 2. The well harvested, rich, fertile land suitable for agriculture.
2. A well harvested, rich, fertile land suitable for agriculture.
2. A well harvested, rich, fertile land suitable for agriculture.

sen.j: 「天府」とも。
sen.e: Also called "Tian-fu (land of abundance)."
sen.cmt: 中国語の「天府」の読み方と意味は、下記のサイトを参考にしました。[http://www.chinese-tools.com/tools/sinograms.html]
sen.e: Also called "Tian-fu (land of abundance)."
Also called 'Tian-fu (land of abundance).'

sen.j: 四川など。
sen.e: Places such as Sichuan.
Places such as Sichuan.
Places such as Sichuan.

sen.j: 「政庁」
sen.e: "Zheng Ting (Government Office)"
sen.cmt: 中国語の「政庁」の読み方と意味は、下記のサイトを参考にしました。[http://www.chinese-tools.com/tools/sinograms.html]
sen.e: "Zheng Ting (Government Office)"
"Zheng Ting (Government Office)"

sen.j: 3. 漢から明代までの中国で、各地に王として封建皇族が軍事と行政の拠点として開いた政庁。
sen.e: 3. Government offices which the feudatory royal family opened, in various areas, as a base of military and public administration within China, from the Ming to Han dynasty.
3. Government offices which the feudal royal family opened in various areas, as a base of military and public administration within China, from the Ming to Han dynasty.
sen.cmt: "feudatory" sounds a bit awkward, and replaced with "feudal"
sen.e: 3. Government offices which the feudal royal family opened in various areas, as a base of military and public administration within China, from the Han to Ming dynasty.

sen.j: 「王府」といった。
sen.e: Also called "Wang Fu (Royal Residence)".
sen.cmt: 中国語の「王府」の読み方と意味は、下記のサイトを参考にしました。[http://www.chinese-tools.com/tools/sinograms.html]
sen.e: Also called "Wang Fu (Royal Residence)".
Also called "Wang Fu (Royal Residence)."

sen.j: 政庁には税穀を備蓄するための蔵が並んでいたことが語源。
sen.e: Derived from the government offices (Zheng Ting) used to have warehouses lined up for storing the tax grains.
Derived from the government offices (Zheng Ting) which used to have lines of warehouses for storing tax grains.
Derived from the government offices (Zheng Ting) which used to have lines of warehouses for storing tax grains.

sen.j: 4. 明代から清代までの中国で、都や主要都市の要所に置かれた皇族の大邸宅。
sen.e: 4. Mansions of royals which were located at key spots in capitals and major cities of China, from the Ming to Qing Dynasty.
4. Royal mansions were located at key spots in capitals and major cities of China, from the Ming to Qing Dynasty.
4. Royal mansions were located at key spots in capitals and major cities of China, from the Ming to Qing Dynasty.

sen.j: 単なる住居だが、上記 1 の王府の名残りで「王府」といった。
sen.e: Just a resident, but it was also called "Wang Fu" derived from the reminder of the above point 1 Wang Fu.
While only a residency, but it was also known as "Wang Fu," derived from the description in point 1 concerning Wang Fu.
While only a residency, but it was also known as "Wang Fu," derived from the description in point 1 concerning Wang Fu.

sen.j: 明初南京の永楽帝、清代北京の恭親王など。
sen.e: Emperor Yongle of Nanjing, in the early Ming Dynasty, or Gongqinwan of Beijing in Qing Dynasty.
Emperor Yongle of Nanjing, in the early Ming Dynasty, or Gongqinwan of Beijing in Qing Dynasty.
Emperor Yongle of Nanjing, in the early Ming Dynasty, or Gongqinwan of Beijing in Qing Dynasty.

sen.j: 「地区」
sen.e: "Di Qu (Area)"
"Di Qu (Area)"
"Di Qu (Area)"

sen.j: 5. 唐代から宋 (王朝)にかけて各地で軍事権と行政権を掌握した節度使が本拠とした地。
sen.e: 5. From Tang Dynasty to Song Dynasty, the area where the military governor, who controlled military and civil authorities in various locations, was based in.
From the Tang to Song Dynasty, the military governor who controlled military and civil authorities in various locations was based in this area.
5. From the Tang to Song Dynasty, the military governor who controlled military and civil authorities in various locations was based in this area.

sen.j: 上記の王府からの発展で「使府」ともいった。
sen.e: Evolves from the above Wang Fu, also called "Shi Fu (Official Posts)".
It then evolved from the above Wang Fu, also called "Shi Fu (Official Posts)."
It then evolved from the above Wang Fu, also called 'Shi Fu (Official Posts).'

sen.j: 広州市、揚州、許昌など「州」がつくものが多い。
sen.e: There are many places with "Zhou" such as Guanzhou City, Yangzhou or Xuchang.
Now, there are many places with "Zhou" such as Guanzhou City, Yangzhou or Xuchang.
Now, there are many places with "Zhou" such as Guanzhou City, Yangzhou or Xuchang.

sen.j: これらの多くが 6 の地名に引き継がれる。
sen.e: Many of them took up to 6 place names.
Many of these places took on the names of up to 6 distinct areas.
Many of these places took on the names of areas mentioned in '6.'
sen.cmt: 原文が分かりにくいのですが、「6」とはセル29の「6.」のことだと思います。その意味で訳出し直しました。

sen.j: 6. 唐から清までの中国で、県の上に置かれた行政区画。
sen.e: 6. Administrative area in prefectures in China from Tang to Qing Dynasty.
6. Administrative area in prefectures in China from the Tang to Qing Dynasty.
6. Administrative area superceeding prefectures in China from the Tang to Qing Dynasty.
sen.cmt: 「県の上」とは県より大きい行政区画という意味で訳出し直しました。

sen.j: 7. 宋代から清代までの中国や北方民族国家で、首都や副都として機能した大都市の副称。
sen.e: 7. In China or Northern national countries of the period from Song Dynasty to Qing Dynasty, sub titles for major cities functioned as capitals or sub capitals.
7. During the Song to Qing Dynasties, sub titles for major cities functioned as capitals or sub capitals in China and Northern national countries.
7. During the Song to Qing Dynasties, sub titles for major cities functioned as capitals or sub capitals in China and Northern national countries.

sen.j: 北宋の開封、南宋の杭州、遼の大同 (山西省)、明の南京市や北京市、清の瀋陽など。
sen.e: Kaifeng of Northern Song, Hangzhou of Southern Song, Datong of Liao Dynasty (Shanxi Province), Nanjing city or Beijing city of Ming Dynasty or Shenyan of Qing Dynasty.
Examples include, Kaifeng of Northern Song, Hangzhou of Southern Song, Datong of Liao Dynasty (Shanxi Province), Nanjing city or Beijing city of Ming Dynasty or Shenyan of Qing Dynasty.
Examples include, Kaifeng of Northern Song, Hangzhou of Southern Song, Datong of Liao Dynasty (Shanxi Province), Nanjing city or Beijing city of Ming Dynasty or Shenyan of Qing Dynasty.

sen.j: 日本
sen.e: Japan
Japan
Japan

sen.j: 中国の「政庁」の意味に由来するもの
sen.e: Derived from the meaning of Chinese "Zheng Ting (Government Office)".
Derived from the meaning of Chinese "Zheng Ting (Government Office)".
Derived from the meaning of Chinese 'Zheng Ting (Government Office).'
sen.cmt: ピリオドを'の中に原文の「」に合わせ"を'に

sen.j: 大宰府： 古代から律令制日本の律令制の時代にかけて、九州・壱岐・対馬を所轄し日本の外交・防衛にあたった機関。
sen.e: Dazaifu: Authority for defense and diplomacy of Japan with jurisdiction over Kyushu, Iki and Tsushima from ancient times to the period of the Ritsuryo system's (criminal, administrative and civil codes) Japan.

Dazaifu: Authority for defense and diplomacy of Japan with jurisdiction over Kyushu, Iki and Tsushima from ancient times to the period of the Ritsuryo system's (criminal, administrative and civil codes) Japan.

Dazaifu: Authority for defense and diplomacy of Japan with jurisdiction over Kyushu, Iki and Tsushima from ancient times to the period of the Ritsuryo system's (criminal, administrative and civil codes) Japan.

sen.j: 国府： 律令制で、国衙を中心に発達した都市。
sen.e: Kokufu: Under the Ritsuryo system, cities developed around Kokuga (provincial headquarters).
Kokufu: Under the Ritsuryo system, cities developed around the Kokuga (provincial headquarters).
Kokufu: Under the Ritsuryo system, cities developed around the Kokuga (provincial government headquarters).
sen.cmt: government補足 他ファイルと合わせる

sen.j: 内大臣府： 明治から昭和の初めにかけて、内大臣府が執務の拠点とした施設及び組織。
sen.e: Naidaijin-fu: Facilities and organization where Naidaijin-fu (Minister of Interior's Office) was based for operation from Meiji to early Showa.
Naidaijin-fu: Facilities and organization where the base of operations for the Naidaijin-fu (Minister of Interior's Office) were located from the Meiji to early Showa period.
Naidaijin-fu: Facilities and organization where the base of operations for the Naidaijin-fu (Minister of Interior's Office) were located from the Meiji to the early Showa period.

sen.j: 枢府：「枢密院」の通称。
sen.e: Sumitsu-in: Vernacular term "Sumitsu-in (Privy Council)".
Sumitsu-in: Vernacular term for "Sumitsu-in (Privy Council)".
Su-fu: Vernacular term for 'Sumitsu-in (Privy Council).'
sen.cmt: ピリオドを'の中に原文の「」に合わせ"を'に原文の1つ目の枢密院はサイトでは、「枢府」となっていましたので、原文を修正し、訳文も修正しました。

sen.j: 総督府： 明治から昭和の初めにかけて外地の総督が執務の拠点とした施設。
sen.e: Sotoku-fu: Facility where government-general used as a base office in foreign parts, from Meiji to early Showa.
Sotoku-fu: Facility used as an office by the government-general in foreign countries from Meiji to early Showa period.
Sotoku-fu: Facility used as an office by the government-general in foreign countries from the Meiji to the early Showa period.

sen.j: 台湾総督府、韓国統監府、朝鮮総督府、関東総督府、関東都督府など。
sen.e: Taiwan Sotoku-fu, Kankoku Sotoku-fu, Chosen Sotoku-fu, Kantototoku-fu (Japan's Guandong Governor-General Office) or Kantototoku-fu.
sen.cmt: 関東都督府が二回繰り返されているようですが、原文どおりそのまま訳させていただいております。
sen.e: Such as the Taiwan Sotoku-fu, Kankoku Sotoku-fu, Chosen Sotoku-fu, Kantototoku-fu (Japan's Guandong Governor-General Office) or Kantototoku-fu.
Such as the Taiwan Sotoku-fu, Kankoku Sotoku-fu, Chosen Sotoku-fu, Kanto Sotoku-fu or Kantototoku-fu (Japan's Guandong Governor-General Office).
sen.cmt: 原文に関東都督府の繰り返しがありましたが、サイトを見ると、1つ目が関東総督府でしたので、原文を修正し、訳文も合わせて修正しました。

sen.j: 総理府： かつて内閣総理大臣が主任大臣として所掌していた行政機関。
sen.e: Souri-fu (Prime Mister's office): General administrative agency which Prime Minister, as the main minister, used to administer.
Souri-fu (Prime Mister's office): General administrative agency which used to be administered by the Prime Minister.
Sori-fu (Prime Mister's office): General administrative agency which used to be administered by the Prime Minister.

sen.j: 内閣府： 2001年の中央省庁再編で総理府を改組した行政機関。
sen.e: Naikaku-fu (Cabinet Office): General administrative agency which Sori-fu became during the central government ministries and agencies reorganization in 2001.
Naikaku-fu (Cabinet Office): A general administrative agency created from the Sori-fu during the reorganzization of the central government ministries and agencies in 2001.
Naikaku-fu (Cabinet Office): A general administrative agency created from the Sori-fu during the reorganization of the central government ministries and agencies in 2001.

sen.j: 大統領府／首相府： 外国の大統領や首相が執務の拠点とする施設の総称。
sen.e: Daitoryo-fu (Office of the President)/Shusho-fu (Prime Minister's Office): General names for the facilities the foreign presidents or prime ministers used as the main office.
Daitoryo-fu (Office of the President)/Shusho-fu (Prime Minister's Office): General names for facilities used by foreign presidents or prime ministers as a main office.
Daitoryo-fu (Office of the President)/Shusho-fu (Prime Minister's Office): General names for facilities used by foreign presidents or prime ministers as a main office.

sen.j: 「世界の官邸」と同義。
sen.e: Same as "World's official residence".
Same as "World's official residence".
Same as 'World's official residence.'
sen.cmt: ピリオドを'の中に原文の「」に合わせ"を'に

sen.j: ホワイトハウス、連邦首相府 (ドイツ)など。
sen.e: White House, The Chancellor's Office (Germany).
White House, The Chancellor's Office (Germany).
White House, The Chancellor's Office (Germany).

sen.j: 中国の「政庁」の意味から「統治者」の概念が日本で独立したもの
sen.e: The concept of "governor", derived from the meaning of Chinese "Zheng Ting", was localized in Japan.
The concept of "governor", derived from the meaning of Chinese "Zheng Ting", was localized in Japan.
The concept of 'governor,' derived from the meaning of Chinese 'Zheng Ting,' was localized in Japan.
sen.cmt: ピリオドを'の中に原文の「」に合わせ"を'に

sen.j: 左府： 律令制の左大臣の唐名。
sen.e: Sa-fu: Tang name (the Tang-system name used for Japanese officers) for Sadaijin (Minister of the Left) under Ritsuryo System.
Sa-fu: Tang name (the Tang-system name used for Japanese officers) for Sadaijin (Minister of the Left) under Ritsuryo System.
Sa-fu: Tang name (the Tang-system name used for Japanese officers) for Sadaijin (Minister of the Left) under Ritsuryo System.

sen.j: 右府： 律令制の右大臣の唐名。
sen.e: U-fu: Tang name for Udaijin (Minister of the Right) under Ritsuryo System.
U-fu: Tang name for Udaijin (Minister of the Right) under the Ritsuryo System.
U-fu: Tang name for Udaijin (Minister of the Right) under the Ritsuryo System.

sen.j: 内府： 律令制の内大臣の唐名。
sen.e: Nai-fu: Tang name for Naidaijin (Minister of Interior) under the Ritsuryo System.
Nai-fu: Tang name for Naidaijin (Minister of Interior) under the Ritsuryo System.
Nai-fu: Tang name for Naidaijin (Minister of Interior) under the Ritsuryo System.

sen.j: 幕府： 律令制の近衛大将の唐名。
sen.e: Bakufu: Tang name for Konoe Daisho (Imperial guard chief) under the Ritsuryo System.
Bakufu: Tang name for Konoe Daisho (Imperial guard chief) under the Ritsuryo System.
Bakufu: Tang name for Konoe Daisho (Imperial guard chief) under the Ritsuryo System.

sen.j: 源頼朝は征夷大将軍任官前に右近衛大将だったことから「幕府」と呼ばれた。
sen.e: MINAMOTO no Yoritomo used to be called "Bakufu" since he was Ukone-no-Daisho (Imperial guard chief of the Right) before becoming Seii-Taishogun (Great unifying leader).
MINAMOTO no Yoritomo used to be called "Bakufu" since he was Ukone-no-Daisho (Imperial guard chief of the Right) before becoming Seii-Taishogun (Great unifying leader).

MINAMOTO no Yoritomo used to be called 'Bakufu' since he was Ukone-no-Daisho (Imperial guard chief of the Right) before becoming Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians").
sen.cmt: Seii-Taishogun (Great unifying leader)→seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians")

sen.j: 後にこれが「将軍の居所」という意味に変遷する。
sen.e: Later, this transitioned into the meaning for "whereabouts of Shogun."
Later, this transitioned into the meaning for "whereabouts of Shogun."
Later, this transitioned into the meaning for 'whereabouts of Shogun.'

sen.j: 内府： 明治から昭和の初めにかけてあった「内大臣府」の通称。
sen.e: Udaijin-fu: Vernacular term "Udaijin-fu "which existed from Meiji to early Showa.
Udaijin-fu: Vernacular term "Udaijin-fu "which existed from Meiji to early Showa.
Nai-fu: Vernacular term for 'Udaijin-fu' which existed from Meiji to early Showa.
sen.cmt: 原文の文頭の内大臣府はサイトでは「内府」となっているので、原文を修正し、訳文も修正。スペース削除for挿入原文の「」に合わせ"を'に

sen.j: 中国の「政庁」の意味から「軍事」の概念が日本で独立したもの
sen.e: The concept of "military" derived from the meaning of Chinese "Zheng Ting" was localized in Japan.
The concept of "military" derived from the meaning of the Chinese term "Zheng Ting," which was localized in Japan.
The concept of 'military' derived from the meaning of the Chinese term 'Zheng Ting,' which was localized in Japan.
sen.cmt: 原文の「」に合わせ"を'にスペース削除

sen.j: 近衛兵令制の五衛府： 律令制で、おもに内裏を警護した五つの組織。
sen.e: Goe-fu of Konoeheiryo-sei (Five imperial guard of the imperial guard system): Five organizations who mainly guarded Dairi, the imperial palace, under the Ritsuryo system.
Goe-fu of Konoeheiryo-sei (Five imperial guard of the imperial guard system): Five organizations who mainly guarded Dairi, the imperial palace, under the Ritsuryo system.
Goe-fu of Konoeheiryo-sei (Five imperial guard of the imperial guard system): Five organizations who mainly guarded Dairi, the imperial palace, under the Ritsuryo system.

sen.j: 近衛兵六衛府： 奈良時代後期に上の五衛府が改組され、左右の近衛府・兵衛府・衛門府からなる六衛府となった。
sen.e: Konoehei Rokue-fu (Six imperial guard): The upper Goe-fu (Five imperial guard) was reorganized in the later Nara period, and became Rokue-fu (Six imperial guard) consisting of each right and left of Konoe-fu (a division of the imperial guard), Hyoe-fu (a division of the imperial guard) and Emon-fu (an order of guards to keep the gates of Heiankyo).

Konoehei Rokue-fu (Six imperial guard): The upper Goe-fu (Five imperial guard) was reorganized in the later Nara period, and became Rokue-fu (Six imperial guard), each consisting of the right and left of Konoe-fu (a division of the imperial guard), Hyoe-fu (a division of the imperial guard) and Emon-fu (an order of guards to keep the gates of Heiankyo).

Konoehei Rokue-fu (Six imperial guard): The upper Goe-fu (Five imperial guard) was reorganized in the later Nara period, and became Rokue-fu (Six imperial guard), each consisting of the right and left of Konoe-fu (a division of the imperial guard), Hyoe-fu (a division of the imperial guard) and Emon-fu (an order of guards to keep the gates of Heiankyo).

sen.j: 鎮守府古代 鎮守府： 古代の陸奥国に置かれた軍政を司る機関。
sen.e: Chinju-fu Kodai Chinju-fu (Ancient military base): The organization to control the military based in the ancient Mutsu Province.
Chinju-fu Kodai Chinju-fu (Ancient military base): An organization to control the military based in the ancient Mutsu Province.
Chinju-fu Kodai Chinju-fu (Ancient military base): An organization to control the military based in the ancient Mutsu Province.

sen.j: 幕府： 鎌倉時代・室町時代には「将軍の居所」を指した。
sen.e: Bakufu: During the Kamakura and Muromachi period, it meant "where Shogun lives".
Bakufu: During the Kamakura and Muromachi period, this meant "the Shogun's whereabouts".
Bakufu: During the Kamakura and Muromachi period, this meant 'the Shogun's whereabouts.'
sen.cmt: 原文の「」に合わせ"を'にピリオドを'の中に

sen.j: 幕府が「将軍を頂点とする中央政府」を意味するようになったのは江戸時代中頃から。
sen.e: Bakufu started to mean "the feudal government headed by a shogun" from around the mid-Edo period.
Bakufu started to mean "the feudal government headed by a shogun" from around the mid-Edo period.
Bakufu started to mean 'the feudal government headed by a shogun' from around the mid-Edo period.

sen.j: 鎮守府海軍 鎮守府： 明治時代に日本の沿岸を五つの海軍区に分け、各海軍区に軍港とともに設置された海軍の拠点。
sen.e: Chinju-fu Kaigun Chinju-fu (Navy base): The Naval base located at military ports of each navel area (Japanese coast was divided into five navy areas).
Chinju-fu Kaigun Chinju-fu (Navy base): Naval bases located at military ports in each navel area (Japanese coast was divided into five navy areas).
Chinju-fu Kaigun Chinju-fu (Navy base): Naval bases located at military ports in each navel area (Japanese coast was divided into five navy areas).

sen.j: 横須賀鎮守府、呉鎮守府、佐世保鎮守府、舞鶴鎮守府が終戦まで存在した。
sen.e: Yokosuka Chinju-fu, Kure Chinju-fu, Sasebo Chinju-fu, and Maizuru Chinju-fu all existed until the end of WWII.
Yokosuka Chinju-fu, Kure Chinju-fu, Sasebo Chinju-fu, and Maizuru Chinju-fu all existed until the end of WWII.
Yokosuka Chinju-fu, Kure Chinju-fu, Sasebo Chinju-fu, and Maizuru Chinju-fu all existed until the end of WWII.

sen.j: 中国の「地区」の意味に由来するもの
sen.e: Derived from the meaning of Chinese "Di Qu".
Derived from the Chinese term "Di Qu".
Derived from the Chinese term 'Di Qu.'

sen.j: 江戸：「幕府の所在地」という意味から、江戸に入ることを「入府」、江戸町内のことを「府中」などといった。
sen.e: Edo: From the meaning of "whereabouts of Bakufu", to enter to Edo was described as "Nyufu" or the town inside of Edo was described as "Fuchu".
Edo: Derived from the meaning of "whereabouts of Bakufu", entering Edo was described as "Nyufu," while the town inside of Edo was described as "Fuchu".
Edo: Derived from the meaning of 'whereabouts of Bakufu,' entering Edo was described as 'Nyufu,' while the town inside of Edo was described as 'Fuchu.'
sen.cmt: 原文の「」に合わせ"を'にコンマとピリオドを'の中に

sen.j: 府藩県制： 明治維新直後にそれまでの幕府直轄地のうち、京都所司代・城代・奉行が支配していた地を「府」と改めたもの。
sen.e: Fu Han Ken-sei (Fu, Han and Ken System): Immediately after the Meiji Restoration, out of Bakufu-ruled lands, the land controlled by Kyoto Shoshidai (the Bakufu-appointed governors of Kyoto), Chatelaines and Bugyo (Shogunate administrators), were reformed as "Fu".

Fu Han Ken-sei (Fu, Han and Ken System): Immediately after the Meiji Restoration, the land controlled by Kyoto Shoshidai (the Bakufu-appointed governors of Kyoto), Chatelaines and Bugyo (Shogunate administrators), which were part of Bakufu-ruled lands, were reformed as "Fu".

Fu Han Ken-sei (Fu, Han and Ken System): Immediately after the Meiji Restoration, the land controlled by Kyoto Shoshidai (the Bakufu-appointed governors of Kyoto), Chatelaines and Bugyo (Shogunate administrators), which were part of Bakufu-ruled lands, were reformed as 'Fu.'
sen.cmt: 原文の「」に合わせ"を'にピリオドを'の中に

sen.j: 箱館府・江戸府・神奈川府・越後府・新潟府・甲斐府・度会府・奈良府・京都府・大阪府・長崎府。
sen.e: Hakodate-fu, Edo-fu, Kanagawa-fu, Chico-fu, Niigata-fu, Kai-fu, Watarai-fu, Nara-fu, Kyoto-fu, Osaka-fu and Nagasaki-fu.
sen.cmt: 京都府、大阪府は、現存しておりますが、「府」の例として、Kyoto Prefectureとは訳さずに、そのままKyoto-fuと言う風にさせていただきました。
sen.e: Examples include Hakodate-fu, Edo-fu, Kanagawa-fu, Chico-fu, Niigata-fu, Kai-fu, Watarai-fu, Nara-fu, Kyoto-fu, Osaka-fu and Nagasaki-fu.
Examples include Hakodate-fu, Edo-fu, Kanagawa-fu, Echigo-fu, Niigata-fu, Kai-fu, Watarai-fu, Nara-fu, Kyoto-fu, Osaka-fu and Nagasaki-fu.

sen.j: 廃藩置県までに六府が廃止され三府が残った。
sen.e: Until the Haihan-chiken (Abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures), six Fu domains were abolished and three Fu domains were left.
Until the Haihan-chiken (Abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures), six Fu domains were abolished and three Fu domains were left.
Until the Haihan-chiken (Abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures), six Fu domains were abolished and three Fu domains were left.

sen.j: 三府： 明治から昭和にかけて存在した東京府・京都府・大阪府。
sen.e: Sampu (Three urban prefectures): Tokyo-fu, Kyoto-fu and Osaka-fu prefectures existed from Meiji to Showa period.
Sampu (Three urban prefectures): Tokyo-fu, Kyoto-fu and Osaka-fu prefectures existed from the Meiji to Showa period.
Sanpu (Three urban prefectures): Tokyo-fu, Kyoto-fu and Osaka-fu prefectures existed from the Meiji to the Showa period.

sen.j: 1943年（昭和18年）に東京が「都」となり、京都・大阪の二府が残った。
sen.e: In 1943, Tokyo became "To", and two Fu domains of Osaka and Kyoto were left.
In 1943, Tokyo became "To", and two Fu domains of Osaka and Kyoto were left.
In 1943, Tokyo became 'To,' and two Fu domains of Osaka and Kyoto were left.
sen.cmt: 原文の「」に合わせ"を'にコンマを'の中に

sen.j: 植民地統治下の朝鮮において、主要都市に置かれた行政区画。
sen.e: Under the colonial administration of Korea, administrative districts placed in the major cities.
Under the colonial administration of Korea, administrative districts were placed in major cities.
Under the colonial administration of Korea, administrative districts were placed in major cities.

sen.j: 内地の市に相当。
sen.e: Equivalent of city in the home country.
Equivalent of city in the home country.
Equivalent of city in the home country.
